The voltage-gated proton channel Hv1 is involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of Hv1. We use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of Hv1. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the Hv1 channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric Hv1 channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the dimeric Hv1. Climate change will likely lead to more frequent extreme heat events, which will reduce crop yields. However, the impact of heat on crop yields depends on the temperature at which it occurs. We use global datasets of maize production and climate variability to quantify how yield variability will change in the world’s major maize-producing and -exporting countries under 2 °C and 4 °C of global warming. Our results show that the probability of simultaneous production losses greater than 10% in any given year increases from 0% to 7% under 2 °C warming and to 86% under 4 °C warming. This increase in instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the 800 million people living in extreme poverty, underscores the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. Our results also highlight the importance of understanding the impact of temperature variability on crop yields. This is a critical step toward developing effective adaptation strategies.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of identifying species-level taxa in herbivore feces. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant species (six wild, one domestic) in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. These results suggest that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. Our results highlight the need to consider the taxonomic resolution of diet data when studying the drivers of biodiversity in African savanna. Plastic debris is one of the most widespread forms of marine pollution. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. Using data from the Malaspina 2010 circumnavigation, regional surveys, and previously published reports, we show that the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of plastic debris larger than 1 mm by the ocean interior. This sink may involve a combination of fast nano-fragmentation of the microplastic into particles of microns or smaller, their transference to the ocean interior by food webs and ballasting processes, and processes yet to be discovered. Resolving the fate of the missing plastic debris is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of the solar system is one of the most important questions in astrophysics. The solar system is a unique laboratory for studying the early solar system environment. We determined the ages of 40 large presolar silicon carbide grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. The grains have ages of 3.9 ± 1.6 Ma to ∼3 ± 2 Ga before the start of the Solar System ∼4.6 Ga ago. A majority of the grains have interstellar lifetimes of <300 Ma, which is shorter than theoretical estimates for large grains. This suggests that the solar system formed in a different environment than the interstellar medium. The grains acquired the bulk of their cosmogenic nuclides in the interstellar medium and not by exposure to an enhanced particle flux of the early active sun. This indicates that the solar system formed in a pristine environment.

The ability to design and manufacture complex mechanical devices with desired behaviors is of great importance for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a digital synthesis approach to synthesize composite structures with multiple material phases to precisely achieve arbitrary and extreme prescribed responses under large deformations. The synthesized structures exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate through sophisticated deformation mechanisms to produce the target behaviors. The proposed synthesis, multimaterial fabrication, and heteroassembly strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications.

These results suggest a mechanism for chronoregulation of fetal and adult hemoglobin expression in humans. Our data indicate that LCCBs promote vascular remodeling through STIM-mediated activation of ORAI. Our findings provide a rationale for the use of LCCBs in elderly patients or patients with advanced hypertension and/or onset of cardiovascular remodeling, where levels of STIM and ORAI are elevated. Our data indicate caution against the use of LCCBs in patients with cardiovascular disease. This study provides a mechanistic explanation for the association of LCCBs with heart failure and may lead to the development of new strategies for the treatment of cardiovascular diseases. Our results also highlight the need for a more holistic approach to forest management that considers the full range of ecosystem services and values.

Here we present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We show that the lake underwent large-scale changes in hydroclimate, which resulted in dramatic shifts in the effective moisture of the region and large-scale changes in the landscape and biodiversity of the region.

We compared the effects of reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device (LE-eBook) with reading a printed book in the hours before bedtime. Participants reading an LE-eBook took longer to fall asleep and had reduced evening sleepiness, reduced melatonin secretion, later timing of their circadian clock, and reduced next-morning alertness than when reading a printed book. These results demonstrate that evening exposure to an LE-eBook phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. Beetles are arguably the most speciose group of animals, but the evolutionary history of beetles, including the impacts of plant feeding on beetle diversification, remain poorly understood. We used a comprehensive dataset of 154 beetle genomes and transcriptomes to trace the evolution of beetle genes enabling symbiont-independent digestion of lignocellulose, the major component of plant cell walls. Our analyses resolved previously controversial beetle relationships and dated the origin of Coleoptera to the Carboniferous. We also traced the evolution of genes encoding enzymes that beetles use to digest plant tissues, including those that enable them to feed on plants. Our results suggest that these genes may have been key to the Mesozoic diversification of herbivorous beetles—remarkably, both major independent origins of specialized herbivory in beetles coincide with the first appearances of an arsenal of genes encoding enzymes that enable them to feed on plants. These findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of plant-feeding beetles and the origin of beetle diversity.

We have used TRAP1-null cells and transient TRAP1 silencing/overexpression to show that TRAP1 regulates a metabolic switch between oxidative phosphorylation and aerobic glycolysis in immortalized mouse fibroblasts and in human tumor cells. TRAP1-deficiency promotes an increase in mitochondrial respiration and fatty acid oxidation, and in cellular accumulation of tricarboxylic acid cycle intermediates, ATP and reactive oxygen species. At the same time, glucose metabolism is suppressed. TRAP1-deficient cells also display strikingly enhanced invasiveness. TRAP1 interaction with and regulation of mitochondrial c-Src provide a mechanistic basis for these phenotypes. Taken together with the observation that TRAP1 expression is inversely correlated with tumor grade in several cancers, these data suggest that, in some settings, this mitochondrial molecular chaperone may act as a tumor suppressor. This study provides a mechanistic explanation for the role of TRAP1 in cancer and suggests that TRAP1 may be a potential target for cancer therapy. (PsycINFO Database Record

Actin depolymerizing factor (ADF) is a key regulator of actin filament dynamics. It is known to sever actin filaments, but the mechanism by which it does so is not understood. Here, we show that ADF can induce a mechanical torque on actin filaments, which enhances severing. This mechanochemical mechanism is critical for ADF to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our results provide a mechanistic explanation for how ADF can sever actin filaments in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress. Our findings have implications for understanding the role of ADF in various cellular processes, including cell migration and cytokinesis. They also provide a general principle for understanding the role of mechanical forces in regulating the activity of other molecular motors and enzymes. Finally, they suggest that mechanical forces can be harnessed to control the activity of molecular motors and enzymes in vitro and in vivo.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is often promoted as a healthier alternative to glucose, a common sugar found in many foods and beverages. However, the relative appetite-suppressing effects of fructose versus glucose remain unclear. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may be a weaker appetite suppressant than glucose. Our results have implications for understanding the impact of sweeteners on appetite and food intake. They also have implications for the design of future studies aimed at determining the effects of sweeteners on health outcomes. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean that exhibits a unique combination of cultural, linguistic, and genetic traits from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample genomic diversity across Madagascar and found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations, with a limited contribution from Europe and the Middle East. The distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. These results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the genetic consequences of the human colonization of the island. They also highlight the importance of considering the spatial resolution of the sampling when studying the genetic diversity of human populations. This is particularly important for the study of island populations, where the genetic structure is often influenced by the history of the island itself.

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others in a large social network. This finding has implications for understanding the spread of emotions in society, and for the design of social media platforms.

The presence of chemical modifications in messenger RNAs (mRNAs) has been known for decades, but the impact of these modifications on protein synthesis has been difficult to study. We have developed a method to reconstitute the bacterial translation system and human cells to test the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis. Our work reveals that the presence of pseudouridine (Ψ) in messenger RNA can modestly alter translation speed and increase the rate of near-cognate aminoacyl-tRNA binding. These findings suggest that mRNA modifications can have subtle effects on translation that may be important for cell function. Our study also provides a method to study the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis that can be used to study other chemical modifications in the future. (Less)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, more social and economic engagement, and a healthier lifestyle. These associations are robust across a range of demographic and socioeconomic factors, and over a 4-y period. The feeling that life is filled with worthwhile activities may promote healthy aging and help sustain meaningful social relationships and optimal use of time at older ages.

The evolution of body size in mammals is a central question in evolutionary biology. The aquatic environment imposes unique constraints on body size, but the extent to which these constraints are driving the evolution of aquatic mammals remains unclear. We use a combination of comparative phylogenetic analysis and examination of the fossil record to test the hypothesis that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals. We find that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving the evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals. This result is consistent with energetic constraints on body size imposed by the aquatic environment. Our results suggest that the evolution of aquatic mammals is not an evolutionary dead end.

The temperature dependence of viral growth is a key factor in the pathogenesis of many respiratory viral infections. In this study, we show that mouse airway cells infected with a mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures found in the nasal cavity than at core body temperature. We also show that the temperature-dependent growth phenotype is dependent on the MAVS protein, a key signaling adaptor of the RIG-I–like receptors (RLRs). These findings provide insight into the mechanism of temperature-dependent growth of respiratory viruses and may have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. The type IV pili of bacteria are major surface adhesins that are involved in a wide range of biological processes, including biofilm formation and pathogenicity. Here we show that type IV pili of P. aeruginosa are also involved in a mechanosensory system that detects surface contact and regulates the expression of virulence factors. This mechanosensory system is based on the interaction of the type IV pilus motor with a chemosensory protein, PilJ, which in turn regulates the activity of the type IV pilus motor. This mechanochemical model for surface sensing is unique among known bacterial sensory systems and suggests that type IV pili may be involved in a broader range of mechanosensory processes than previously thought. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the role of pili in bacterial surface sensing and virulence. They also have implications for the development of antibiofilm strategies. Finally, they highlight the importance of type IV pili as a mechanosensitive sensor in bacterial biology.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically in recent decades, and this trend is expected to continue. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We provide a comprehensive analysis of the global pesticide situation and show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a profound impact on human society, and the discovery of SARS-CoV-2 in animals has raised concerns about the potential for spillback into wildlife and the reemergence of the virus. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in white-tailed deer, a species that is susceptible to severe disease and can act as a reservoir for other coronaviruses. We also show that SARS-CoV-2 can be transmitted between deer, and that the virus is circulating in deer during the winter months, when human cases are declining. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic and the need for a proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. Our results highlight the urgent need for a robust and proactive “One Health” approach to study the ecology, molecular evolution, and dissemination of SARS-CoV-2. This study is a step toward a better understanding of the ecology of SARS-CoV-2 and the potential for spillback into wildlife.

The hydropower industry has been building dams in the developing world since the 1970s. The same problems are being repeated: disrupting river ecology, deforestation, losing aquatic and terrestrial biodiversity, releasing substantial greenhouse gases, displacing thousands of people, and altering people’s livelihoods plus affecting the food systems, water quality, and agriculture near them. This paper studies the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam along with some of the governance and compensation challenges. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is a neurodegenerative disorder that is characterized by chronic inflammation. However, the origin of this inflammation is still unclear. In this study, we show that soluble and oligomeric amyloid-β (Aβ) are the major toxic species that trigger an inflammatory response in neurons. We demonstrate that neurons are the major source of inflammatory factors in the brain, and that the extent of this response correlates with the risk of developing AD. Our findings suggest that the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ may be a significant contributor to the AD pathogenesis.

The earliest evidence for economic exploitation of chickens is still unknown. The results of our faunal analysis demonstrate that the Hellenistic (fourth–second centuries B.C.E.) site of Maresha, Israel, is the earliest site known today where economic exploitation of chickens was widely practiced. We base our claim on the exceptionally high frequency of chicken bones at that site, the majority of which belong to adult individuals, and on the observed 2:1 ratio of female to male bones. These results are supported further by an extensive survey of faunal remains from 234 sites in the Southern Levant, spanning more than three millennia, which shows a sharp increase in the frequency of chicken during the Hellenistic period. We further argue that the earliest secure evidence for economic exploitation of chickens in Europe dates to the first century B.C.E. and therefore is predated by the finds in the Southern Levant by at least a century. We suggest that the gradual acclimatization of chickens in the Southern Levant and its gradual integration into the local economy, the latter fully accomplished in the Hellenistic period, was a crucial step in the adoption of this species in European husbandry some 100 y later.

The folding of a protein is a complex process that is not yet understood. The most common approach is to study the folding of a single protein, but this is limited by the complexity of the process. Here we study the folding of a large protein, maltose binding protein, by a method that allows the study of the folding of a single protein at high resolution. We find that the folding of the protein is a complex process that involves distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. These results add a large protein to the list of proteins known to fold through distinct native-like intermediates in distinct pathways. This list is growing, and it is becoming clear that the folding of large proteins is more complex than previously thought. Dinucleoside tetraphosphates are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress and are thought to function as signaling molecules. In bacteria, the predominant decapping enzyme, ApaH, is inactivated by the very conditions of disulfide stress that enable accumulation of alarmones. Here, we show that, in cells experiencing such stress, the pyrophosphohydrolase RppH assumes a leading role in decapping those transcripts, preferring them as substrates over their triphosphorylated and diphosphorylated counterparts. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the cellular response to stress and the evolution of RNA-based signaling. (Less)

Sepsis is a major cause of mortality worldwide. Although there are several therapeutic strategies to reduce mortality, there is no specific treatment to restore immune function after sepsis. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression in sepsis. We found that citrulline, a nonessential amino acid, was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study also provides evidence for the use of citrulline as a potential therapeutic strategy to treat sepsis. The biomass of the biosphere is a key parameter for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined, and that the global marine biomass pyramid contains more consumers than producers. Our analysis highlights the importance of the global biomass of humans and the need for a more complete understanding of the biomass of wild mammals. Finally, we provide a global perspective on the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. This work is a step toward a global census of the biomass of all taxa.

Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system can be in a critical state and yet the system is not in equilibrium. SOC systems are characterized by the presence of a power-law distribution of activity, and the system’s activity is self-regulated to a critical value. The sandpile model is the archetypal SOC system. In this paper, we describe a continuous model of SOC, which is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models and their relation to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena. Our aim is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for quantum applications, but its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly under mechanical strain without phonon instability. This opens up opportunities to control the electronic and optical properties of diamond via strain engineering for quantum applications. We also show that diamond can be demetallized reversibly under tensile strain, which can be used to control the phase transition to graphite. These findings offer opportunities for tailoring properties of diamond via strain engineering for electronic, photonic, and quantum applications. Our findings are expected to be useful for the development of diamond-based quantum devices. This work also provides a general framework for exploring the mechanical properties of solids. The neural network-based machine learning approach developed in this work can be used to explore the mechanical properties of other materials. The strain-induced metallization/demetallization phenomena can be explored in other materials as well.

The discovery of antimicrobial peptides in plants and animals has led to the development of a new class of fungicides. However, the mode of action of these peptides against plant fungal pathogens is not well understood. Here, we report the antifungal activity of a structurally unique NCR peptide against plant fungal pathogens and demonstrate its mode of action. The results provide insights into the mode of action of this class of peptides and pave the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. This work also highlights the potential of the model legume Medicago truncatula for the discovery of novel antimicrobial peptides. The male–female reproductive interface is a critical site of interaction that is likely to be important for the success of all internally fertilizing species. However, the extent to which the female reproductive tract contributes to the life history of sperm is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins become more prevalent in sperm after mating and that they support sperm viability during the prolonged period between copulation and fertilization. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work provides a foundation for future studies aimed at understanding the extent to which sperm–FRT interactions contribute to reproductive success. (Less)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets to prevent bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause the common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force application to platelets switches the VWF A1 domain to a second state with faster on-rate, providing a mechanism for activating VWF binding to platelets. This mechanism is important for understanding the pathophysiology of VWD. The results are relevant to understanding the role of force in other protein interactions. The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been studied for decades. However, the study of the viral component of the microbiome has been more challenging. This study provides a comprehensive database of human-associated viruses, which is the largest of its kind. The database is used to uncover previously unknown associations between viruses and disease. The results provide a foundation for future research on the role of viruses in human health.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is a key process in the climate system. However, the ACI is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is because of the complexity of the ACI process and the lack of observational capability. To overcome this conundrum, we introduce the dual-field-of-view (FOV) high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL) for simultaneously profiling aerosol and water cloud properties, especially water cloud microphysical properties. This instrument is expected to become a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. The observations obtained from the dual-FOV HSRL constitute substantial and significant additions to understanding ACI process. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. This paper is expected to provide a significant contribution to the understanding of ACI.

The temperature history of the Earth is a key factor in understanding the origin and evolution of life. The temperature inferred from isotopic evidence for the early Earth is lower than that inferred from the thermostability of reconstructed ancestral enzymes. This discrepancy has been subject to question due to uncertainties regarding oceanic isotopic compositions, diagenetic or metamorphic resetting of the isotopic record, and depositional environments. Our results provide a new method for assessing the temperature history inferred from isotopic evidence, and suggest that Earth’s surface temperature decreased over geological time from ∼65–80 °C in the Archean, a finding consistent both with previous isotope-based and protein reconstruction-based interpretations. Interdisciplinary studies such as those reported here integrating genomic, geologic, and paleontologic data hold promise for providing new insight into the coevolution of life and environment over Earth history. (Less summary)

Ion channels are the main regulators of ion flow in the body. They are also the targets of many diseases. The activation and inactivation of ion channels are important for their function. The activation gate is the main site of channel opening and is usually located at the intracellular end of the channel. The inactivation gate is the main site of channel closing and is usually located at the selectivity filter. We found that the BK channel lacks an activation gate and normally shows no C-type inactivation. We also found that the BK channel’s C-type inactivation is closed state-dependent and that its extents and rates inversely correlate with channel-open probability. Because C-type inactivation can involve multiple conformational changes at the selectivity filter, we propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. Our findings may help us understand the mechanism of the BK channel’s normal closing and its disease-related opening. They may also provide a new approach for the development of drugs for diseases caused by the BK channel’s abnormal opening. (Less simplification is needed.)

Malaria parasite invasion of the red blood cell (RBC) is a critical step in the disease pathogenesis. The parasite erythrocyte-binding antigen 175 (EBA175) is required for parasite invasion in most parasite strains. Here, we show that EBA175 binding to glycophorin A (GPA) on the RBC surface leads to an increase in the cytoskeletal tension of the red cell and a reduction in the bending modulus of the cell’s membrane. We isolate the changes in the cytoskeleton and membrane and show that reduction in the bending modulus is directly correlated with parasite invasion efficiency. These data suggest that the malaria parasite primes the erythrocyte surface through its binding antigens, altering the biophysical nature of the target cell and thus reducing a critical energy barrier to invasion. This finding would constitute a major change in our concept of malaria parasite invasion, suggesting it is, in fact, a balance between parasite and host cell physical forces working together to facilitate entry. This work provides a new perspective on the invasion process and could lead to the development of new strategies for malaria control. (Less)

Diamond is a promising material for quantum applications, but its electronic and optical properties are sensitive to defects and impurities. In this work, we show that diamond can be metallized, without defects, by applying strain. This opens up the possibility of tailoring the properties of diamond by strain engineering. We also show that diamond can be demetallized, without defects, by applying tensile strain. This can be used to control the phase of diamond, which is important for applications such as diamond-based quantum computing. Our results pave the way for strain engineering of diamond for quantum applications.

Influenza virus is a major cause of morbidity and mortality worldwide. In temperate regions, seasonal outbreaks of influenza virus correlate with decreases in ambient humidity. While low humidity is known to enhance viral transmission, its impact on host response to influenza virus infection and disease outcome remains unclear. Here, we show that housing mice in low relative humidity makes them more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza A virus. We find that exposure to dry air impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low relative humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the impact of dry air on host defense and disease outcome during influenza virus infection. They also suggest that dry air may be a modifiable risk factor for influenza virus transmission and severity. Our study may also have implications for understanding the impact of dry air on other respiratory viral infections. (PsycINFO Database Record

The brain’s processing of language is often described as a tree, with words at the leaves and phrases at the branches. However, this description is based on a model of language that is not supported by neurophysiological evidence. Here, we show that the brain’s activity during the construction of a sentence follows a tree structure, with each word contributing to the activity of the phrase it belongs to. This suggests that the brain may use a merge operation to combine words into phrases. Our results provide initial evidence for a neural implementation of this operation and suggest that the brain may use it to build a tree-like structure of phrases from the input stream of words.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates that regulates cell fate decisions and tissue patterning. The pathway is regulated by two scaffolds, Axin1 and Axin2, which are similar at the protein level and genetically redundant. We show here that differential regulation of the two genes on the transcriptional and proteostatic level confers differential responsiveness that can be used in tissue-specific regulation. Such subtle features may distinguish other redundant gene pairs that are commonly found in vertebrates through gene knockout experiments. This study provides a unique perspective on the regulation of redundant genes and their functions in tissue-specific regulation. The lateral hypothalamus (LH) is a key region of the brain involved in the regulation of feeding. Electrical stimulation of LH neurons causes animals to eat vigorously, and this effect can be blocked by lesions of LH neurons or the dopamine system. Here we show that stimulation of LH neurons can also induce eating in a region of the ventral tegmental area (VTA) and substantia nigra pars compacta (SNc), but not in the VTA or SNc themselves. We also show that stimulation-induced eating is dependent on a circuit involving LH neurons and the peri-locus coeruleus region of the lateral hypothalamus. Finally, we show that this circuit is not involved in the regulation of hunger or satiety. Thus, we present a characterization of brain circuitry that may promote overeating and contribute to obesity. This circuit may be a potential target for the development of new treatments for obesity. Nitrogen is the most important nutrient for plant growth, and the ability to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis between plants and their nitrogen-fixing bacteria is a key technology for sustainable agriculture. We have developed a system that allows us to control the nitrogen-fixing symbiosis in barley, in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant. This work represents a key milestone toward the development of a synthetic plant-controlled symbiosis in which the bacteria fix nitrogen only when in contact with the desired host plant and are prevented from interaction with nontarget plant species. This technology could be used to improve the efficiency of nitrogen fixation in agriculture and to reduce the use of chemical nitrogen fertilizers. It could also be used to develop a synthetic nitrogen cycle in which nitrogen-fixing bacteria are only active when in contact with the desired host plant. The Peruvian Amazon is the world’s most rapidly deforested tropical forest. The Peruvian government has invested in remote-sensed forest monitoring to detect deforestation and has encouraged community-based monitoring to increase the speed of detection. We study a community-based monitoring program that was randomly assigned to 39 of 76 communities in the Peruvian Amazon. We find that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects are imprecise. Our findings suggest that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to perceive the world around them. The auditory organs of these animals are extremely diverse in anatomy after hundreds of millions of years of evolution, yet they are all made up of cellular tissue and are morphologically part of the body. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. We find that the spider’s web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to sense the motion of web threads, which allows the spider to remotely detect and localize the source of an incoming airborne acoustic wave. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provides unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. This study also provides a unique example of outsourcing and supersizing of sensory function in animals

The health and climate impacts of air pollution are often considered separately. We show that the health benefits of reducing air pollution are much larger than previously thought, and that the climate benefits are even larger. This is because air pollution and climate change are coupled, and because aerosols mask the warming effect of greenhouse gases. Our results indicate that a rapid phaseout of fossil-fuel-related emissions and major reductions of other anthropogenic sources are needed to save millions of lives, restore aerosol-perturbed rainfall patterns, and limit global warming to 2 °C.

The COVID-19 pandemic continues to cause severe illness and death worldwide. Vaccine development efforts have been accelerated, and several promising candidates are nearing approval. However, the high cost of these vaccines may limit their global access. We report a recombinant protein-based vaccine candidate that is suited for large-volume microbial manufacturing and that contains a variant of the receptor-binding domain (RBD) that exhibits enhanced immunogenicity and cross-reactivity with variants of concern. This engineered RBD may be a useful addition to the vaccine development toolbox to address the global COVID-19 pandemic. The engineered RBD and the designed virus-like particle platform described here may also be useful for other emerging and reemerging infectious diseases.

The ligand–receptor interaction between secreted small ALKAL proteins and human ALK and related leukocyte tyrosine kinases (LTK) is a promising target for the treatment of neuroblastoma. In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/LTK family receptors are activated by ALKALs. We further demonstrate that ALKALs are involved in the development of iridophores, neural crest-derived pigment cells. Our results provide evidence for the involvement of ALKALs in neural crest development and suggest ALKALs as potential therapeutic targets for neuroblastoma. Our findings are of general interest for the understanding of ALKALs function in development and for the development of ALKALs as therapeutic targets in cancer.

The emergence of plague from its Yersinia pseudotuberculosis progenitor is a key event in the history of the genus Yersinia, and the timing of this event is still debated. We present 17 Y. pestis genomes from the Late Neolithic to the Bronze Age, which provide a snapshot of the pathogen’s evolution and ecology during this critical period. Our results suggest that the plague lineage we recovered from the Late Neolithic/Early Bronze Age was nonflea-adapted and may have been extinct by the Bronze Age. We also discover the presence of the flea-adapted form of plague in Bronze Age Iberia, suggesting a much wider geographic spread of this form of plague than previously thought. These data provide insights into the formative years of plague and its evolution and ecology during this period. They also provide a unique window into the history of plague in Europe, which is still poorly understood.

This work examines the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity—hegemonic masculinity (HM)—in predicting support for Donald Trump in the 2016 American presidential election and Joe Biden in the 2020 American presidential election. We find that women’s and men’s endorsement of HM predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. HM was associated with less trust in the government, more sexism, more racism, and more xenophobia, but continued to predict unique variance in evaluations of Trump when controlling for each of these factors. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of HM legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. They also have implications for understanding the role of masculinity in the 2020 American presidential election. (Less)

The fate of soil organic carbon (SOC) in agricultural systems is a critical question for the future of agriculture and the global climate. In the United States, the conversion of native grasslands to crop production has released massive amounts of SOC to the atmosphere. We show that soil health management practices can sequester SOC in agricultural systems, but the efficacy of these practices depends on the type of crop production system. Our results highlight the potential of diverse, rotationally grazed pasture management to sequester SOC on agricultural lands. These results have implications for the future of agriculture and the global climate. They also highlight the importance of integrating livestock into agricultural systems to mitigate climate change. This study is part of a larger effort to understand the role of agricultural systems in climate-smart agriculture.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a better understanding of the risk of spillover of novel viruses from wildlife to humans. We developed a framework to identify and prioritize wildlife viruses with the greatest potential to spill over and cause disease in humans. We used this framework to prioritize 887 wildlife viruses for further investigation. The SpillOver platform is a living database that can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. We hope that SpillOver will be used to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks.

Nectar is a reward that plants offer to pollinators for pollination services. The color of nectar is often used as a cue for pollinator attraction, but the underlying mechanisms are poorly understood. Here, we show that the red color of the nectar of the plant Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid, nesocodin. We also identify nesocodin in the red nectar of the hummingbird-visited Jaltomata herrerae and provide molecular evidence for convergent evolution of this trait. Our findings suggest that only a limited number of compounds are likely to underlie this type of adaptation. This work provides a molecular basis for the evolution of a visually important trait in plants and opens up new avenues for the study of the evolution of color in plants.

We present a genome-wide analysis of a large sample of individuals from Bavaria, Germany, dating mostly to the late 5th/early 6th century AD. Our data indicate that while men generally had ancestry that closely resembles modern northern and central Europeans, women exhibit a very high genetic heterogeneity; this includes signals of genetic ancestry ranging from western Europe to East Asia. Particularly striking are women with artificial skull deformations; the analysis of their collective genetic ancestry suggests an origin in southeastern Europe. In addition, functional variants revealed that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. These results indicate that complex demographic processes during the Early Medieval period may have contributed in an unexpected way to shape the modern European genetic landscape.

The receptor usage and cell entry activity of the surface spike protein of bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5 are investigated. The results suggest that bat coronaviruses have the potential to cause cross-species transmission to humans. These findings are of great importance for understanding the origin of the Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) and for preventing future MERS-CoV outbreaks.

We describe a large-scale, resource-scarce setting mNGS pathogen surveillance study of undifferentiated febrile illness. We demonstrate that mNGS can be used to rapidly identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens. We show that mNGS can be used to identify pathogens that are underappreciated in the region, such as Plasmodium knowlesi and leptospirosis. We also show that mNGS can be used to identify emerging pathogens, such as chikungunya virus. These findings have implications for resource-scarce settings, where outbreaks are likely to emerge, but where laboratory diagnostics and bioinformatics capacity are limited. Coordinated and ongoing mNGS pathogen surveillance can better identify the breadth of endemic, zoonotic, or emerging pathogens and deployment of rapid public health response. This study highlights the potential of mNGS to rapidly identify pathogens in resource-scarce settings. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The human genome is replicated in a process called DNA replication fork progression. This process is driven by the activity of DNA polymerases, which synthesize new DNA strands from the template. The lagging strand DNA polymerase δ (pol δ) is responsible for synthesizing the DNA strand that is complementary to the template strand. In humans, pol δ is anchored to the proliferating cell nuclear antigen (PCNA) sliding clamp to form a holoenzyme. The stability of this complex is integral to every aspect of lagging strand replication. We developed unique kinetic assays to analyze the processivity and stability of the pol δ holoenzyme. Our results indicate that the human pol δ holoenzyme maintains a loose association with PCNA while replicating DNA. Such behavior has profound implications on Okazaki fragment synthesis in humans as it limits the processivity of pol δ on undamaged DNA and promotes the rapid dissociation of pol δ from PCNA on stalling at a DNA lesion. This work provides a unique perspective on the stability of the pol δ holoenzyme and its implications for DNA replication. It also provides a foundation for future studies on the role of the PCNA sliding clamp in DNA replication.

The origin of life is one of the most important and enduring questions in biology. In the hypothesized RNA world, before the evolution of proteins, genetic information was stored in RNA molecules that were replicated by ribozymes. In the laboratory, RNA molecules can replicate other RNA molecules, but the process is inefficient. In this paper, we describe a method for improving the activity of RNA molecules, which allows them to replicate other RNA molecules with high fidelity. This method can be used to improve the activity of RNA molecules that can replicate other RNA molecules, and thus can be used to reconstruct the RNA world in the laboratory.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

The clinical characteristics of severe and critical COVID-19 patients are analyzed, and the therapeutic effect of tocilizumab is evaluated. The results show that tocilizumab is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Copper is an essential micronutrient for all organisms, but its excess is toxic. The ability to control copper levels is therefore a key to the survival of all organisms. In this study, we demonstrate that the xan BGC of Aspergillus fumigatus encodes a copper-binding isocyanide siderophore. This is the first example of a fungal natural product that binds copper. The copper-dependent antimicrobial properties of xan BGC-derived isocyanides suggest a role for these compounds in the control of copper levels in the environment and in the host–fungus interaction. The existence of the xan BGC in several filamentous fungi suggests a heretofore unknown role of eukaryotic natural products in copper homeostasis and mediation of interactions with competing microbes. These findings have implications for our understanding of the role of natural products in fungal biology and for the control of copper levels in the environment. The formation of tridymite, a low-pressure, high-temperature polymorph of silica, is a unique feature of the sedimentary record of Lake Gale, Gale crater, Mars. The presence of tridymite in a laminated mudstone at Marias Pass, Gale crater, is consistent with the formation of this mineral in a silicic volcanic environment. The diagenesis of the laminated mudstone at Marias Pass is also consistent with the formation of the primary amorphous silica and the post-lithification mineral phases. The impact of late-spring frosts (LSFs) on plants and animals is widespread, but the geographic distribution of LSFs and the evolutionary impact of these events on plants are poorly understood. We use a large dataset of LSFs and the resistance strategies of woody plants to infer that trees in regions where LSFs are common are cautious in their leaf-out strategies, while trees in regions where LSFs are rare are opportunistic. We further show that the frequency of LSFs in Europe and Asia is increasing, and that this trend will likely increase the risk of frost damage in these regions. Our findings can inform land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy. They also provide a framework for understanding the impact of other climate extremes on plants and animals.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory infiltrate in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, it is unclear whether Th17 cells are required for disease or are merely part of the inflammatory milieu. We found that Th17 cells could directly contribute to disease by transitioning to Th1-like cells and that they could also support the development of classic Th1 cells. These results suggest that Th17 cells are important mediators of disease in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. Understanding the mechanisms by which Th17 cells contribute to disease may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins and by toxic effects of misfolded proteins. We report a method to rapidly produce motor neuron-like astrocytes from living ALS patients. These astrocytes are toxic to motor neurons, suggesting that they are a major cause of disease. We also show that astrocytes from ALS patients with different genetic causes are toxic to motor neurons, suggesting a common mechanism. This method will enable rapid screening of drugs to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity and accelerate ALS research and development of therapies. It will also enable the production of large quantities of astrocytes for disease modeling and drug screening. This will be of great benefit to ALS research and development of therapies. (Less)

The gut microbiota of Ixodes scapularis ticks plays a critical role in the ability of the pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum to colonize the vector. We now show that A. phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein (iafgp), which alters the gut microbiota and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix. IAFGP binds the terminal d-alanine residue of the pentapeptide chain of bacterial peptidoglycan, resulting in altered permeability and the capacity of bacteria to form biofilms. These data elucidate the molecular mechanisms by which a human pathogen appropriates an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides a mechanistic understanding of how a human pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to more effectively colonize its vector. This knowledge will be critical for the development of strategies to control vector-borne diseases. (Less)

The evolution of the avian body plan is one of the most important evolutionary transitions in the history of vertebrates. The discovery of a new basal pygostylian, Jinguofortis perplexus, adds important information about the origin of the short-tailed bird group. The presence of a fused scapulocoracoid in adult individuals independently evolved in Jinguofortisidae and Confuciusornithiformes may relate to an accelerated osteogenesis during chondrogenesis and likely formed through the heterochronic process of peramorphosis by which these basal taxa retain the scapulocoracoid of the nonavian theropod ancestors with the addition of flight-related modifications. The discovery of Jinguofortis increases the known ecomorphological diversity of basal pygostylians and highlights the importance of developmental plasticity for understanding mosaic evolution in early birds. (Less)

We show that stratospheric water vapor variations play an important role in the evolution of our climate. This comes from analysis of observations showing that stratospheric water vapor increases with tropospheric temperature, implying the existence of a stratospheric water vapor feedback. We estimate the strength of this feedback in a chemistry–climate model to be +0.3 W/(m2⋅K), which would be a significant contributor to the overall climate sensitivity. One-third of this feedback comes from increases in water vapor entering the stratosphere through the tropical tropopause layer, with the rest coming from increases in water vapor entering through the extratropical tropopause. This finding is important for understanding the causes of past climate change and for predicting future climate change. It also has implications for the design of climate experiments in climate models. Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue, and even yellow and green. In some species, these colors are produced by pigments, but in others, they are produced by proteins. In this study, we show that the green color of anurans (frogs and toads) is produced by a group of proteins that bind biliverdin, a molecule that is normally found in the blood. Our results provide a molecular and functional explanation for the evolution of green color in anurans and other vertebrates that have green tissues. Our findings also suggest that the serpin superfamily, the largest group of protease inhibitors, has a broader function than previously thought.

The ability of breast cancer cells to maintain their stemness properties in hypoxic conditions is critical for the development of metastasis. We show that hypoxia induces expression of the m6A demethylase AlkB homolog 5 (ALKBH5), which increases the expression of pluripotency factors and the breast cancer stem cell (BCSC) phenotype. ALKBH5 expression is induced by hypoxia through the HIF-1α and HIF-2α pathways, and is required for the BCSC phenotype. ALKBH5 expression is increased in human breast cancer tumors, and its expression can be used as a biomarker for the identification of BCSCs. Thus, ALKBH5 expression in breast cancer cells is induced by hypoxia through the HIF pathway, and may be a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of breast cancer. (PsycINFO Database Record

The use of fetal animal skins for parchment has been a long-standing controversy in codicology. The term abortivum in Latin has been used to suggest that the skins were from aborted animals, but this has been challenged by others. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript, consistent with the local availability of hides. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. This method could be used to identify the animal origin of parchment in the future.

The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The age model for this event is critical for understanding its cause and the controls on extinction/recovery dynamics. We present a precise age model for the extinction based on U-Pb dates from five volcanic ash beds. The age of the extinction is constrained to 251.941 ± 0.037 and 251.880 ± 0.031 Mya, an interval of 60 ± 48 ka. The carbon cycle reorganization that preceded the extinction is punctuated by a sharp (3‰) negative spike in the isotopic composition of carbonate carbon. The carbon cycle volatility persists for ∼500 ka before a return to near preextinction values. The precise age model will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction, allowing insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion. The age model will also be critical for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms.

Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic inflammatory disease of the gastrointestinal tract, which is characterized by the overactivation of the immune system. IBD is a heterogeneous disease, and the exact pathogenesis is still unclear. In this study, we found that retinoic acid-related orphan receptor α (RORα) is crucial for maintaining intestinal homeostasis by attenuating nuclear factor κB (NF-κB) transcriptional activity. RORα deletion in intestinal epithelial cells (IECs) leads to excessive intestinal inflammation and highly activated inflammatory responses in the dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) mouse colitis model. Transcriptome analysis reveals that deletion of RORα leads to up-regulation of NF-κB target genes in IECs. Chromatin immunoprecipitation analysis reveals corecruitment of RORα and histone deacetylase 3 (HDAC3) on NF-κB target promoters and subsequent dismissal of CREB binding protein (CBP) and bromodomain-containing protein 4 (BRD4) for transcriptional repression. These results suggest that RORα/HDAC3-mediated attenuation of NF-κB signaling controls the balance of inflammatory responses, and therapeutic strategies targeting this

The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target for developing vaccines and therapeutics. The D614G mutation is the most common mutation in the spike protein of currently circulating SARS-CoV-2 viruses. We use cryo-electron microscopy to compare the structure of the spike protein with and without this mutation and show that the mutant spike is more flexible and adopts a range of more open conformations that may facilitate binding to the receptor and subsequent structural rearrangements required for membrane fusion. These results suggest that the D614G mutation may increase the infectivity of the virus. Our results also suggest that the D614G mutation may not be as detrimental to the infectivity of the virus as previously thought. This study provides a structural basis for the increased infectivity of the D614G mutant virus. These results may help in the development of vaccines and therapeutics for the COVID-19 pandemic.
