We consider repeated games with Borel-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with Borel-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs. The result is a generalization of the classical result of Moulin and Zamir (1982) for finite games. Our proof is constructive, in the sense that it provides an algorithm for finding an ε-equilibrium. This algorithm is based on a dynamic programming principle, which is a generalization of the principle of repeated play. Our result is also applicable to the case of infinite games.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has reduced life expectancy at birth by 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y.

The chemical properties of atoms are the basis of chemistry. The chemical hardness and electronegativity are two central properties of atoms, which are the second- and first-order chemical potentials, respectively. We show that these properties decrease with pressure, and we discover that pressure-induced s-d orbital transfer makes Ni, Pd, and Pt “pseudo–noble-gas” atoms with a closed d-shell configuration, and the elements preceding them (Fe and, especially, Co, Rh, and Ir) electron acceptors, while the elements right after them (Cu, Ag, Zn, and Cd) become highly electropositive. We show the explicative and predictive power of our electronegativity and chemical hardness scales. This work is a step toward the understanding of the chemical behavior of atoms under pressure.

Climate change is expected to increase fire activity in many regions, but the impacts on the carbon cycle are uncertain. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression can reduce fire activity and mitigate warming. However, the risk of more extreme fires is also higher, which could lead to more carbon being released from ecosystems. Our results highlight the importance of fire in the carbon cycle and the need to understand the impacts of climate change on fire regimes. This will be critical for assessing the risks of climate change to the carbon cycle and for the development of mitigation strategies.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a widespread strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are not well understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of a symbiont in a light-producing organ of the squid Euprymna scolopes. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, when the squid is active and the symbiont is producing light. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients at specific times of the day may be a general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their symbionts.

Text data are ubiquitous and increasingly important for understanding social phenomena. However, the complexity of text data makes it difficult to identify latent patterns. We introduce a method to identify topics in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. Our method integrates advances in theoretical machine learning with the language modeling capabilities of word embedding. We illustrate our method with a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data. This approach can be applied to many domains and problems.

The Black Death, which originated in Asia, arrived in the Mediterranean harbors of Europe in 1347 CE, via the land and sea trade routes of the ancient Silk Road system. This epidemic marked the start of the second plague pandemic, which lasted in Europe until the early 19th century. This pandemic is generally understood as the consequence of a singular introduction of Yersinia pestis, after which the disease established itself in European rodents over four centuries. To locate these putative plague reservoirs, we studied the climate fluctuations that preceded regional plague epidemics, based on a dataset of 7,711 georeferenced historical plague outbreaks and 15 annually resolved tree-ring records from Europe and Asia. We provide evidence for repeated climate-driven reintroductions of the bacterium into European harbors from reservoirs in Asia, with a delay of 15 ± 1 y. Our analysis finds no support for the existence of permanent plague reservoirs in medieval Europe. This study provides a new perspective on the history of the plague and its spread across Eurasia. It also highlights the importance of climate change in the spread of the disease. (Less)

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web and are important ecosystem engineers. They are also a valuable food resource for many marine animals. However, the population dynamics of at least some asteroid species have recently been affected by a disease that has led to behavioral changes, lesions, loss of turgor, limb autotomy, and death. The disease is characterized by rapid degradation (“melting”). We show that the disease is caused by a densovirus and that the virus is present in plankton, sediments and in nonasteroid echinoderms. The densovirus is therefore the most promising candidate disease agent responsible for asteroid mass mortality.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is the most common form of leukemia and is associated with a poor prognosis. The identification of targets for therapy is therefore of great importance. We show here that the interleukin 1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients, but not on normal hematopoietic stem cells. We demonstrate that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that an antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. The results also suggest that IL-1 signaling may be important for the growth of AML cells. Thus, the results may lead to the development of new therapies for AML. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean that exhibits a unique combination of cultural, linguistic, and genetic traits from both Southeast Asia and Eastern Africa. We used a grid-based approach to sample genomic diversity across Madagascar and found that the Malagasy population is a mixture of Bantu and Austronesian populations. However, the distribution of African and Asian ancestry across the island reveals that the admixture was sex biased and happened heterogeneously across Madagascar, suggesting independent colonization of Madagascar from Africa and Asia rather than settlement by an already admixed population. In addition, a few centuries is sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. Our results provide insights into the settlement history of Madagascar and the genetic consequences of the human colonization of the island. They also highlight the importance of considering the spatial resolution of the sampling when studying the genetic diversity of human populations. This is particularly important for island populations, where the genetic structure is often influenced by the history of the island and the colonization of the island by humans.

Bacteria use small RNAs to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The RNA encodes a 28-amino acid protein that increases dehydrogenase activity. We found that the protein interferes with the activity of the RNA and base pairing interferes with the protein. These results demonstrate that the translation and base-pairing functions compete. This is an example of a dual-function RNA that has been overlooked in the past. The discovery of such RNAs may be important for understanding the evolution of sRNAs. The dual-function RNA described here may also be important for understanding the regulation of carbon utilization in bacteria.

The ability of viruses to mutate and evade the human immune system and neutralizing antibodies remains an obstacle to antiviral and vaccine development. Here, we introduce a deep learning algorithm that efficiently enhances antibody affinity to achieve broader and more potent neutralizing activity against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrate the utility of our approach on a human antibody P36-5D2, which is effective against SARS-CoV-2 Alpha, Beta, and Gamma but not Delta. We show that our algorithm can identify CDR changes that alleviate the impact of two Omicron mutations on the epitope. These results highlight the power of our deep learning approach in antibody optimization and its potential application to engineering other protein molecules. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-2 variants. This work has the potential to accelerate the development of antibody-based therapeutics against SARS-CoV-2 variants.

Crop experts are the primary source of information on crop status in many countries. However, their data is often difficult to access and use. We show how to transform the original categorical data into a continuous probabilistic variable that is more suitable for quantitative analysis. We also show how to use this data to monitor crop status and provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official forecasts released midseason. Our results demonstrate the potential of using crop expert data to monitor crop status and provide early warnings of crop anomalies. This approach can be extended to other agricultural and environmental variables.

Language is a complex system that involves the ability to integrate information over time. The brain is thought to use a variety of mechanisms to achieve this integration. However, the neurobiological substrate of memory in language is not well understood. Here we propose a mechanism that relies on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons to store information. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be accessed directly without cued retrieval. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of great interest to the scientific community and the public. However, the majority of studies have been conducted at a single site, limiting our ability to understand the response of soil respiration to climate change. Here, we present the largest global dataset of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements, and use this dataset to investigate the response of soil respiration to climate change. Our results provide limited evidence of acclimation of soil respiration to experimental warming in several major biome types, and demonstrate that rising global temperatures may result in regionally variable responses in soil respiration, with colder climates being considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our results highlight the need for more studies to investigate the response of soil respiration to climate change. This is critical to improving our mechanistic understanding of how soil carbon dynamics change with climatic warming.

The molecular evolution of plastid genomes is a powerful tool for studying the evolution of photosynthetic organisms. The molecular signature of the transition from autotrophy to a nonphotosynthetic parasitic lifestyle is still poorly understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to parasitism. We show that the transition to obligate parasitism relaxes functional constraints on plastid genes in a stepwise manner. Our findings suggest that the molecular signature of the transition to obligate parasitism is not only linked to the loss of photosynthesis but also to the establishment of a parasitic lifestyle. The evolutionary rates of plastid genes are a sensitive indicator of the macroevolutionary events that accompany the transition to parasitism. Our model can be used to predict the molecular signature of the transition to parasitism in other photosynthetic organisms.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the risks of climate change in water-scarce regions. We use a high-resolution climate model to estimate the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5 [SSP2-4.5]) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. They also highlight the importance of regional climate modeling for understanding the risks of climate change in water-scarce regions. (Less)

The discovery of quasicrystals in nature has been a major advance in the field of materials science. However, the conditions under which they form are not fully understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this new quasicrystal, Si61Cu30Ca7Fe2, provides a link between the discovery of naturally occurring quasicrystals and the creation of the oldest anthropogenic quasicrystal. This discovery also demonstrates that quasicrystalline structures can form under conditions of extreme pressure and temperature, and that the discovery of new quasicrystal-forming systems is still possible today.

The formation of the isocyclic fifth ring in (bacterio)chlorophylls is a key reaction in photosynthesis. The mechanism of this reaction has remained elusive for more than 60 y. This paper describes the discovery of three classes of the enzyme that catalyzes this reaction, and their evolution is discussed.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases, including multiple sclerosis (MS). Neuroactive protein kinase ASK1 has been implicated in neuroinflammation, but its precise cellular and molecular mechanisms remain unknown. In this study, we generated conditional knockout (CKO) mice that lack ASK1 in T cells, dendritic cells, microglia/macrophages, microglia, or astrocytes, to assess the roles of ASK1 during experimental autoimmune encephalomyelitis (EAE). We found that ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages and astrocytes ameliorated EAE severity, whereas ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE. ASK1 signaling in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in generating and maintaining disease. Activated astrocytes produce key inflammatory mediators, including CCL2, that further activated and recruited microglia/macrophages, in an astrocytic ASK1-dependent manner. Astrocyte-specific analysis revealed CCL2 expression was higher in the later stage compared with the early stage, suggesting a greater proinflammatory role of astrocytes in the later stage. Our findings suggest glial ASK1 as a promising therapeutic target for reducing neuroinflammation.

The 2012–2014 drought in California was the most extreme in the state’s instrumental record. We show that the probability that a drought year will occur is more than twice as likely if precipitation deficits occur during warm conditions. We also show that the probability of drought has increased in the past two decades, and that the probability of drought has increased further in recent years. Finally, we show that anthropogenic forcings have increased the probability that dry precipitation years are also warm. These findings suggest that anthropogenic warming is increasing the probability of co-occurring warm–dry conditions that have created the acute human and ecosystem impacts associated with the 2012–2014 drought. Continued warming will increase the probability of drought in California and other regions. Thus, the 2012–2014 drought is a harbinger of future climate change.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability and a complicated etiology. Therefore, it has been challenging to identify the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms such as social deficit, repetitive behaviors, and behavioral inflexibility. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk genes with diversified molecular functions all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. These findings provide a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and suggest that forgetting is a potential therapeutic target for autism. This study also provides a framework for the identification of the causal paths that lead to the core autistic symptoms. (PsycINFO Database Record

This work is the most comprehensive cross-national demonstration of negativity biases to date. It also highlights individual-level variation in responsiveness to news content. The results suggest that there may be reason to reconsider the conventional journalistic wisdom that “if it bleeds, it leads.”

The CRAC channel is a key regulator of cellular Ca2+ signaling. Mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein ORAI1 or the Ca2+ sensor STIM1 result in severe immune dysfunction and nonprogressive myopathy. Here, we identify gain-of-function mutations in the cytoplasmic domain of STIM1 and in the pore-forming protein of the CRAC channel that cause congenital bleeding disorders. These data expand our understanding of the phenotypic spectrum of dysregulated CRAC channel signaling, advance our knowledge of the molecular function of the CRAC channel, and suggest new therapies aiming at attenuating store-operated Ca2+ entry in the treatment of patients with Stormorken syndrome and related pathologic conditions. This study also provides a molecular basis for the clinical phenotype of Stormorken syndrome. (PsycINFO Database Record

The spread of protein aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases is a key feature of the disease process, but the mechanisms underlying this process are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to monitor the spread of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We demonstrate that the release of aggregates requires N-ethylmalemide–sensitive fusion protein 1, indicating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. These results provide a model for the spread of aggregates in neurodegenerative diseases and suggest that targeting the mechanisms underlying this process may be a potential therapeutic strategy. This approach could be extended to other neurodegenerative diseases. (Less)

Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, our understanding of the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats is very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. These findings may help to prevent or control future viral outbreaks. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the immunology of bats and may help to identify potential therapeutic targets for the treatment of immune-mediated diseases in humans. The one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth, and is provided by folate. Cancer cells have defects in folate metabolism, and thus depend on the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) for one-carbon unit supply. Here we report the discovery of a pyrazolopyran scaffold that inhibits plant SHMT, and the development of dual SHMT inhibitors for cancer therapy. We show that SHMT inhibition is particularly effective in B-cell lines, and that this effect is rooted in defective glycine import. Thus, defective glycine import is a targetable metabolic deficiency of DLBCL. Our results suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising therapeutic strategy for B-cell malignancies. Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a heterogeneous disease with a variety of genetic mutations in proteins that are highly aggregation-prone. These proteins form intracellular inclusion bodies that are characteristic of different neuropathological subtypes of the disease. The inclusion bodies are composed of a variety of proteins that do not share obvious characteristics other than coaggregation. However, recent evidence from other neurodegenerative disorders suggests that proteins that are supersaturated in the cell can form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord. Here, we show that the inclusion bodies of mutant SOD1, TDP-43, and FUS are supersaturated even more than the native interaction partners of these three proteins. These results suggest that inclusion bodies in various forms of ALS result from a set of proteins that are metastable in motor neurons, and thus prone to aggregation upon a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in this specific setting. This study provides a unifying explanation for the neuropathology of ALS. The band structures of the 2D photonic crystals are predicted to produce unconventional atom–light interaction behaviors, including anisotropic emission, suppressed spontaneous decay, and photon-mediated atom–atom interactions controlled by the position of the atomic array relative to the photonic crystal. The device configuration also enables application of optical tweezers for controlled placement of atoms. Devices can be fabricated reliably from a 200-nm silicon nitride device layer using a lithography-based process, producing predicted optical properties in transmission and reflection measurements. The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The first flowering plants were aquatic plants that colonized the surface of the water. The study of Montsechia, a very early flowering plant, is a step forward in our understanding of the origin of the flowering plants. Montsechia is a plant that lived and reproduced below the surface of the water, similar to Ceratophyllum, the living representative of the aquatic flowering plants. Montsechia is the oldest known aquatic flowering plant and opens the possibility that aquatic plants were locally common at a very early stage of angiosperm evolution.

The evolution of viruses is often inferred from genetic sequences of contemporary viruses. However, viruses can evolve rapidly, and it is important to understand how viruses evolve in the past. Here we present the genomes of five ancient human parvovirus B19 (B19V) viruses from human remains that are up to ∼6.9 thousand years old. We find that B19V has been associated with humans for a long time, and that the most recent common ancestor of all B19V is placed ∼12.6 kya. We also find that the recombination event that formed the most common B19V genotype 2 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 kya. These findings emphasize the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. They also provide a unique opportunity to study the evolution of ancient viruses.

Sea level is a key indicator of global climate change because it is rising at a rate that is unprecedented over the past century. We show that the rate of sea level rise is accelerating, which is consistent with the findings of the IPCC AR5. The acceleration is not uniform, however, and we find that the rate of acceleration is increasing. This implies that the rate of sea level rise will continue to accelerate in the future.

Pain is a common and costly problem in America today. We show that pain has increased with age for all adults, but that the increase has been more rapid for those born after 1950. This erosion of working-class life is not limited to pain, but is part of a broader erosion of working-class life for those born after 1950.

The ability to characterize the structure and dynamics of enzyme active sites is critical for understanding the mechanisms of catalysis. Here, we demonstrate the utility of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the structure and reactivity of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This integrated approach provides insight into the location and orientation of crystallographic waters within the active site, the protonation states of ionizable sites, and the tautomeric equilibria of the intermediate. The chemically detailed, three-dimensional structure from NMR-assisted crystallography is key to understanding why the natural substrate indole reacts, but not benzimidazole, in the subsequent reaction step. This work highlights the potential of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme reactions. (Less)

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe respiratory disease caused by a coronavirus. There is no licensed antiviral treatment for MERS, and the current standard of care is supportive care. We show that remdesivir, an antiviral drug that is approved for use in other diseases, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of continued research into the development of antiviral treatments for emerging and reemerging coronaviruses. This is an important step forward in the fight against MERS and other emerging coronaviruses.

The provision of nutrients to symbiotic microbes is a common strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their mutualistic associations. However, the mechanisms by which this is achieved are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to maintain the health of a symbiont in a light-producing organ of the squid Euprymna scolopes. We also show that the glycan is provided and metabolized only at night, when the squid is active and the symbiont is producing light. These results suggest that the provision of nutrients at specific times of the day may be a general strategy used by animals to maintain the health of their symbionts.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades, with disproportionate impact on students of color and students with disabilities. This study tests whether teachers’ mindsets about discipline can be changed through scalable intervention. In three districts, teachers were randomized to receive a brief, online intervention that encouraged them to adopt an empathic rather than punitive mindset about discipline. Evaluated at five middle schools, this intervention halved year-long suspension rates from 9.6% to 4.8%. It also bolstered respect the most at-risk students, previously suspended students, perceived from teachers. Teachers’ mindsets about discipline directly affect the quality of teacher–student relationships and student suspensions and, moreover, can be changed through scalable intervention. This study has implications for the future of US schools.

DNA alkylation is a major source of DNA damage that can lead to mutagenesis and cancer. However, the molecular mechanisms of DNA alkylation-induced mutagenesis remain largely unknown. In this study, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcription. We found that the transcription reaction is stalled at alkylated DNA template. The stalling is exacerbated by the proofreading activity of RNA polymerase II. We also found that the stalling and mutagenesis are controlled by distinct fidelity checkpoints. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II that is involved in modulating the translocation of alkylated DNA template after nucleotide incorporation opposite the lesion. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) causes severe respiratory disease in humans. To better understand how sequential proteolysis contributes to MERS-CoV infection, we introduced mutations that blocked the first cleavages of MERS-CoV spike (S) glycoproteins. These mutations severely compromised MERS-CoV infection into human lung-derived cells, but had little effect on infection into several other cell types. These cell type-specific requirements for proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses trafficked past cell-surface proteases and into endosomes, whereas precleaved viruses used endosomal fusion-activating proteases to effect the second fusion-activating cleavages during cell entry. Uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. The food system is a major driver of environmental degradation and a leading cause of biodiversity loss. The food choices of the global population are a key lever for reducing the environmental impacts of food production and consumption. However, the food system is also a major contributor to obesity and other health problems. Increasing the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering settings is a simple and effective way to reduce the environmental impacts of the food system while improving population health. Our results provide robust evidence to support the potential for simple changes to catering practices to make an important contribution to achieving more sustainable diets at the population level. Our findings have implications for catering managers, food manufacturers, and policymakers. They also highlight the potential for “nudging” to increase the proportion of vegetarian meals available in catering settings.

The cell surface proteome is a dynamic interface for the cell to interact with the extracellular space. We applied quantitative proteomics to a panel of oncogenes and found that each oncogene has a different surfaceome, but that the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. We also found massive oncogene-induced changes to the glycoproteome, and differential increases in complex hybrid glycans, especially for KRAS and HER2 oncogenes. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a step toward understanding the role of the cell surface proteome in cancer. The data are also available at ProteomeXchange with identifier PXD01899.

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the effects of vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. These findings support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our findings suggest that vote-by-mail is a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid development of diagnostic tests and vaccines. The development of a vaccine is a long-term endeavor, and in the meantime, we need to understand the mechanisms of SARS-CoV-2 infection and develop strategies to mitigate the severity of the disease. Here, we report the crystal structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which provides insights into the immune evasion and disease severity mechanisms of SARS-CoV-2. The structure also provides a foundation for the development of diagnostic and therapeutic strategies. Hypoxia is a common environmental stressor that can cause cerebral edema. However, the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema in rats and that this is mediated by the hypoxic release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF) from the hypothalamus. CRF acts on the cerebral cortex via its receptor CRFR1 to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular basis for the development of cerebral edema in hypobaric hypoxia. They also suggest that CRFR1 antagonists may be a potential therapeutic approach for the treatment of cerebral edema in hypobaric hypoxia. The scientific method is based on the idea that we can learn from experience. But what if we have not experienced everything? What if we are only able to experience a small subset of all possible events? This is the problem of selective inference. We describe some recent developments in selective inference and illustrate their use in forward stepwise regression, the lasso, and principal components analysis.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that directly induce EC development remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can induce the formation of functional vascular ECs (ETVECs) from human fibroblasts. ETV2-induced ETVECs exhibit EC characteristics in vitro and form mature functional vascular networks in vivo. Furthermore, ETVECs significantly improve blood flow recovery in a hind limb ischemic model using BALB/c-nu mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the generation of ECs for therapeutic purposes. The receptor tyrosine kinases (RTKs) ALK and LTK are involved in a variety of human cancers. In addition, they are involved in the development of the eye and the skin. Here, we show that the zebrafish orthologs of these RTKs are involved in the development of the eye and the skin. We also show that the zebrafish orthologs of the ligands of these RTKs are involved in the development of the eye and the skin. These results establish a physiological link between the ligands of RTKs and the development of the eye and the skin. They also provide a model system to study the function of these ligands in zebrafish. Finally, they provide a model system to study the function of RTKs in zebrafish.

Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. Accumulating evidence indicates that STING plays an important role in the regulation of insulin sensitivity. However, its function in β-cell remains unknown. Herein, we found that STING deficiency in β-cells and peripheral tissues caused glucose intolerance, suggesting a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. We also found that STING is decreased in islets of T2D patients and mice, indicating a possible role of STING in β-cell dysfunction. Indeed, STING deficiency in β-cells decreased expression of β-cell function–related genes, contributing to impaired GSIS. Mechanistically, STING deficiency in β-cells down-regulated Pax6 expression, which led to loss of nuclear localization of Pax6 and impaired GSIS. These findings revealed a function of STING in the regulation of insulin secretion and established pathophysiological significance of fine-tuned STING within β-cells and insulin target tissues for maintaining glucose homeostasis. These findings also provide a potential therapeutic target for T2D. (PsycINFO Database Record

Influenza A viruses are the most important cause of human influenza epidemics and pandemics. They are composed of eight genomic RNA segments, which are packaged into virions. The packaging of the viral genome is a critical step in the assembly of the virions, but the molecular details of this process are still unknown. Here, we identified a direct interaction between two viral RNA segments of an influenza A virus. This interaction is required for optimal viral replication and favors the copackaging of the interacting RNA segments. Our results indicate that the interaction between viral RNA segments is a key step in the selective packaging of the influenza A virus genome. This interaction might limit genetic reassortment between divergent influenza A viruses. Our findings could therefore have important implications for the development of influenza vaccines and antiviral drugs. (PsycINFO Database Record

The role of YAP/TAZ in mediating mechanotransduction and vascular homeostasis has been extensively studied. However, the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions has not been investigated. In this study, we found that YAP/TAZ activation is induced by disturbed flow and is associated with the development of atheroprone phenotypes. In addition, statin, an antiatherosclerotic drug, inhibits YAP/TAZ activation and attenuates the development of atherosclerotic lesions. These results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising athero-protective therapeutic strategy. Our study provides a mechanistic understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in the flow regulation of atheroprone endothelial phenotypes and the consequential development of atherosclerotic lesions. It also provides a rationale for the development of athero-protective drugs targeting YAP/TAZ. This study may also have implications for the understanding of the functional role of YAP/TAZ in other vascular diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

Wildfire is a natural process that has been a part of the Earth system for millennia. However, human activities have greatly increased the spatial and temporal extent of wildfire in the United States and elsewhere. This has led to increased economic and ecological costs of wildfire, as well as increased risk to human life and property. This paper provides a comprehensive analysis of the causes of wildfire ignitions and their spatial and temporal extent in the United States. Actions to reduce the economic and ecological costs of wildfire should focus on reducing the number of human-caused ignitions.

We introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We connect changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods with economic and demographic data and find that three factors predict neighborhood improvement: (i) densely populated neighborhoods with college-educated residents are more likely to experience physical improvements; (ii) neighborhoods with better initial appearances experience, on average, larger positive improvements; and (iii) neighborhood improvement correlates positively with physical proximity to the central business district and to other physically attractive neighborhoods. Together, our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities.

Natural repellents are a promising alternative to chemical pesticides for pest control. However, the molecular targets of these plant-derived compounds in arthropods remain to be elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that mediates the avoidance behavior of scorpions toward Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents. We also found that dTRPγ ion channel in Drosophila melanogaster is a chemosensory receptor of natural repellents, which mediates avoidance behavior. This study provides a molecular target of natural repellents in arthropods and should help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. It should also help to understand the arthropod–plant adaptation. (PsycINFO Database Record

The recent Zika virus (ZIKV) outbreak has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the dynamics of ZIKV within the host may be important. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV dynamics in a nonhuman primate model, allowing for characterization of the growth and clearance of ZIKV within individual macaques. We show that the rate of viral production is rapid and the eclipse phase for ZIKV is likely short. We also show that antiviral treatment can be effective in reducing the time to undetectable plasma viral load. However, the timing of treatment is critical, and the treatment must be given before the peak of viremia to be effective. These results can help guide the development of effective treatment strategies. (Less)

Coral bleaching is a well-known phenomenon that occurs when corals lose their symbiotic zooxanthellae, resulting in the loss of the majority of the coral’s photosynthetic capacity. The underlying causes of bleaching are still poorly understood, and it is unclear whether the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is a consequence of the environmental stress or a precondition for bleaching. Here, we show that the metabolic and molecular responses of the coral Stylophora pistillata to heat stress are a consequence of the altered nutrient cycling of the coral holobiont. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to predict the stability of the coral–algal symbiosis in a changing environment.

The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the host from the environment. In the case of cancer, the epithelium becomes leaky and allows the dissemination of cancer cells to other organs. Here, we show that intestinal tumors can alter the composition of the microbiome and that the dysbiotic microbiome can trigger a regenerative response that stimulates tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The treatment of breast cancer with chemotherapy may result in the emergence of cancer stem cells or tumor-initiating cells, which have an enhanced capacity for self-renewal, tumor initiation, and/or metastasis. In this study, we show that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 is increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also show that the expression of ROR1 enhances the capacity of breast cancer cells to invade Matrigel, form spheroids, engraft in Rag2−/−γc−/− mice, or survive treatment with paclitaxel. Finally, we show that treatment of mice bearing breast cancer patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab repressed expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and impaired the capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. The start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often attributed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that the start of this event is coincident with the eruption of Mount Takahe, a small volcano in West Antarctica, and that the eruptions led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which plausibly led to changes in Southern Hemisphere climate. This finding challenges the attribution of the start of accelerated Southern Hemisphere deglaciation to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies. The Mount Takahe eruptions are the most distant volcanic eruptions known to have caused stratospheric ozone depletion. The findings have implications for the interpretation of past volcanic eruptions and the role of stratospheric ozone depletion in past climate change. Freshwater fisheries are an essential source of food, recreation, and livelihoods, but are often overlooked in global assessments. We present a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that 90% of global catch comes from river basins with above-average stress levels. We also show that freshwater fisheries provide the equivalent of all dietary animal protein for 158 million people, highlighting the critical role of rivers in providing locally sourced, low-cost protein. However, the spatial coincidence of productive fisheries and low food security underscores the high stakes for improving fishery management. Our enhanced spatial data on estimated catches can facilitate the inclusion of inland fisheries in environmental planning to protect both food security and species diversity. Our findings highlight the need to protect the world’s rivers from the impacts of human activities.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge, and aqueous Li-ion batteries draw large attention for this purpose. However, the energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited due to the narrow electrochemical stable potential window of aqueous electrolytes. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable Mo-based oxide is delivered with a large capacity and low potential without triggering decomposition of water. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. The ability to regenerate after injury is a fundamental property of the nervous system that is lost in the adult mammalian CNS. In this study, we identify a form of regeneration that is independent of the MAPK signaling pathway and is instead triggered by physical lesion of a sensory dendrite. This form of regeneration is reminiscent of a well-studied form of endogenous activity-dependent ectopic axon outgrowth in the same neuron type. These connections suggest that this DLK-independent regeneration represents a powerful platform for gene discovery in neuronal regeneration. Moreover, we note numerous similarities between DLK-independent regeneration and lesion conditioning, a phenomenon producing robust regeneration in the mammalian CNS. Taken as a whole, our study unites disparate forms of regeneration to uncover fresh molecular insights into activity-dependent control of the adult nervous system’s intrinsic regenerative capacity.

Recombination is a fundamental process in the evolution of genomes. In sexually reproducing organisms, it is responsible for the exchange of genetic material between homologous chromosomes during meiosis, which ensures that each offspring receives a set of chromosomes that is identical to its parent, except for the random mutations that occur during DNA replication. In the past, we have used shotgun resequencing of a wild population of the monkeyflower Mimulus guttatus to precisely locate over 400,000 boundaries of historic crossovers or gene conversion tracts. Their distribution defines some 13,000 hotspots of varying strengths, interspersed with cold regions of undetectably low recombination.

The resting brain is a dynamic system, with fluctuations in blood oxygen level-dependent (BOLD) signal representing a small fraction of total neuronal activity. The analysis of these fluctuations has led to the identification of networks of brain regions that are functionally and anatomically connected and that are anatomically and functionally related. Here, we show that the dominant resting state network in healthy subjects is topographically similar to the default mode network. In Parkinson’s disease, this dominant network is subordinated to a disease-related pattern. Network function was assessed by quantifying the expression of resting state networks during task performance. Network deactivation was reduced in early Parkinson’s disease, and this abnormality was partially corrected by dopaminergic therapy. In Alzheimer’s disease, significant reductions in network expression were already present at diagnosis, progressing over time. These results illustrate the potential of metabolic imaging to provide useful information regarding the resting organization of the brain in health and disease.

The 5′ cap structure is the most important modification of mRNA. It is required for efficient translation and is the target of many posttranscriptional regulatory mechanisms. The existence of other 5′ modifications in eukaryotes is unknown. We describe a 5′ NAD+ cap structure in yeast and show that it is produced cotranscriptionally on subsets of nuclear and mitochondrial encoded mRNAs. The 5′ NAD+ cap may have important functions in regulating translation of specific classes of mRNA.

Metabolic memory is the prolonged beneficial effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the progression of microvascular complications in the long-term follow-up Epidemiology of Diabetes Interventions and Complications (EDIC) Study. We show that epigenetic DNA-methylation differences at specific loci in whole blood and blood monocytes persist for several years during the EDIC Study and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer and has no targeted therapy. We show that the tumor suppressor protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is expressed in the majority of TNBCs and is associated with poor prognosis. FSIP1 deficiency in TNBC cells promotes autophagy, enhances AMP-activated protein kinase (AMPK) signaling, and decreases mechanistic target of rapamycin (mTOR) and Wnt/β-catenin activity. These mechanisms may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. Our findings uncover a role of FSIP1 as well as mechanisms underlying FSIP1 action in drug sensitivity and may, therefore, aid in design of TNBC therapies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Alcohol dependence is a chronic and relapsing disorder that affects millions of people worldwide. The biological mechanisms underlying the development of alcohol dependence are still poorly understood. In this study, we show that some alcohol-dependent subjects develop gut leakiness, which is associated with psychological symptoms of the disease. Moreover, we found that gut leakiness is associated with alterations in the composition and activity of the gut microbiota. These results suggest that the gut microbiota may be involved in the development of alcohol dependence and may represent a previously unidentified target in the management of this disease.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals, many of which are nitrogenous compounds. The biosynthetic pathways of these compounds are not known, and the sources of nitrogen for the production of these compounds are not understood. Here we report the identification of a gene essential for the production of all nitrogenous volatiles in tomato fruit. We also show that this gene encodes a flavin-dependent monooxygenase that catalyzes sequential hydroxylations to produce the diverse set of nitrogenous volatiles. This work provides a major step forward in understanding the biosynthesis of tomato flavor and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biochemistry and flavor chemistry. (Less)

The relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is a key concept in ecology, but it is often investigated separately from other factors that may influence ecosystem processes. Here we show that changes in temperature can alter the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning, and that this relationship is likely to become even more important in a changing climate. Our results highlight the importance of considering the impacts of climate change on biodiversity in the context of the broader threat of biodiversity loss.

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub for spatial memory. It is thought to encode the spatial layout of the environment in the form of a map, with grid cells representing local space. However, the anatomical and functional organization of this map is not fully understood. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in the MEC of freely moving mice. We found that grid cells are strongly coupled, while border, head-direction, and object-vector cells are weakly coupled. These findings suggest that grid cells might form a distinct network from border, head-direction, and object-vector cells. Our results provide a detailed view of the functional organization of MEC neurons during natural behavior. They will be useful for understanding the mechanisms of spatial memory. They will also be useful for developing new tools for studying the brain in natural behavior.

Flowering is a complex process that is controlled by a variety of environmental and internal signals. In many plants, flowering is regulated by a mobile signal, FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT), which is synthesized in leaves and able to travel to the shoot apex to induce flowering. Dodder is a parasitic plant that is able to synchronize its flowering with that of its host. We show that the FT gene in dodder does not function in flowering induction, but rather in flowering synchronization. This study illustrates how flowering regulation can be modified by parasitic plants, here allowing the dodder to synchronize its flowering with that of their hosts. This may be an important means of flowering regulation for parasitic plants, which are often under strong selection to synchronize their flowering with that of their hosts.

The dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system is a critical component of the brain’s reward and movement control circuitry. We show that the dopamine-containing neurons of this system form specialized integrative units within the system. These units, here termed “striosome–dendron bouquets,” are composed of striosomal fibers that are tightly intertwined with dopamine-containing dendrites and other cell types. The striosome–dendron bouquets likely play a critical role in the control of movement and reward. Given the role of striosomes in mood and motivation, the striosome–dendron bouquets could also be involved in the control of these functions. Understanding the organization of the dopamine-containing nigrostriatal system will be critical to understanding its function in health and disease.

We all know it when we feel it: When two people are connected, they “click.” But how do we know when two people are connected? We asked pairs of friends and strangers to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. For both friends and strangers, speed in response was a robust predictor of feeling connected. Conversations with faster response times felt more connected than conversations with slower response times, and within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. The temporal scale of these effects (<250 ms) precludes conscious control, thus providing an honest signal of connection. Using a round-robin design in each of six closed networks, we show that faster responders evoked greater feelings of connection across partners. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the primary pacemaker of the heart. The SAN is composed of specialized cardiomyocytes, which are responsible for heart rate control. The SAN is also the site of action potential initiation, and the precise timing of action potential initiation is critical for heart rate control. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN and is required for the maintenance of the SAN. We also show that STIM1 regulates the function of the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN by regulating the activity of store-operated Ca2+ entry channels and the activity of L-type Ca2+ current. These studies reveal a previously unknown role for STIM1 in the maintenance of SAN function. (PsycINFO Database Record

The beneficial effects of silicon (Si) on plant resistance against insect herbivores have been well documented. However, the underlying mechanisms are still unclear. Here, we show that silicon pretreatment of rice plants increases resistance against the rice leaffolder, a major insect pest of rice, by priming jasmonate (JA) signaling and promoting the accumulation of silicon in rice plants. These results suggest that silicon and JA may interact to promote plant resistance against insect herbivores. Our findings may provide insights into the mechanisms of silicon-mediated insect resistance in plants. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is still poorly understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is involved in the metabolism of ether lipids. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the function of macrophages in innate immunity. Our results suggest that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is a potential target for the treatment of inflammatory diseases.

Language is a complex system that requires the integration of information over time. The brain is thought to use a variety of mechanisms to accomplish this, but the neurobiological substrate of memory remains unclear. Here we propose a mechanism that is based on the adaptive changes in excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to integrate information over time. We show that this mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to integrate information over time. This work provides a step toward a computational neurobiology of language.

The delivery of biomolecules to plants is a major challenge in plant biology. The cell wall, which is absent in mammalian cells, is the dominant physical barrier to biomolecule delivery to plants. Here, we show that DNA nanostructures can deliver biomolecules across the cell wall and demonstrate that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are the key design parameters for plant cell internalization and gene silencing. Our work establishes the feasibility of biomolecule delivery to plants with DNA nanostructures and also details the design parameters of importance for plant cell internalization and also assesses the impact of DNA nanostructure geometry for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be of interest to the plant biology and nanotechnology communities.

Nutrient loading from small tributaries is often overlooked in efforts to reduce nutrient pollution in lakes and rivers. However, we show that small tributaries can be a significant source of nutrients to coastal areas. We found that the 6 largest tributaries of Lake Michigan accounted for ∼70% of the daily nutrient loads delivered to the lake. However, the nutrient loads from small tributaries were disproportionately higher in dissolved inorganic forms, suggesting that they may be a significant source of coastal nutrient pollution. Our findings highlight the importance of small tributaries in coastal eutrophication and the need to address them in efforts to reduce nutrient pollution. This is especially important in large lakes and rivers, where the relative importance of small tributaries may be underestimated.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is biased toward rare combinations of chemical concentrations. We find that the long-time dynamics of such systems are biased toward states that exhibit a fine-tuned extremization of environmental forcing. This behavior is reminiscent of the “fine-tuning problem” in cosmology, where the environment is biased toward rare combinations of cosmological parameters that are required to support life. Our results suggest that the fine-tuning problem may be more general than previously thought, and may be relevant to a wide range of complex systems.

The mechanisms underlying the paroxysmal EEG abnormalities in autoimmune encephalitis are poorly understood. Here we show that NMDAR-Ab–induced changes in cortical microcircuitry can lead to paroxysmal EEG abnormalities. We validate a dynamic causal model of NMDAR-Ab effects on cortical microcircuitry and use this model to identify the key synaptic parameters that best explain EEG paroxysms in pediatric patients with NMDAR-Ab encephalitis. Finally, we show that NMDAR-Ab–related changes render microcircuitry critically susceptible to overt EEG paroxysms when these key parameters are changed. These findings offer mechanistic insights into circuit-level dysfunction induced by NMDAR-Ab. They also provide a framework for understanding the effects of other types of autoimmune encephalitis on brain function. This framework may be useful for the development of new treatments. (Less)

The Earth system is currently experiencing a rapid climate change, and it is important to understand how the system responded to abrupt warming in the past. Here, we present a multiproxy approach to investigate an abrupt climate change event that occurred during a glacial period. We show that the event was associated with a global warming and a doubling of atmospheric CO2. The warming was linked to an increase in nutrient fluxes and to a biodiversity nadir. The event was also associated with an injection of organic matter–derived carbon into the ocean, which can be linked to the development of anoxia. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms that can lead to rapid climate change and biodiversity loss. They also highlight the importance of organic matter in the Earth system and the need to better understand the role of organic matter in the past.

The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. Despite its widespread use, the impact of certification on tropical deforestation remains unclear. We use a unique dataset of oil palm plantations to evaluate the impact of RSPO certification on deforestation and fire. We find that certification reduced deforestation by 33% from a counterfactual of 9.8 to 6.6% y−1. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results suggest that certification is not a silver bullet for tropical deforestation. Rather, it is a tool that can be used in combination with other policies to achieve conservation and climate goals.

The exocyst complex is a multisubunit complex that is involved in the final steps of exocytosis. Dysfunction of the exocyst complex is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. The small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and offers a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. The results also provide a deeper understanding of the function of the exocyst complex and its regulation. This study is expected to be useful for the development of new drugs for human diseases. Sex determination is a fundamental feature of animal biology, and the genetic basis of sex determination is a major focus of evolutionary biology. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single locus, but in others, multiple loci interact to produce more than two sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles in the cichlid fish Metriaclima mbenjii, where two alleles, one for female and one for male sex, interact to produce four possible sex classes. We find that multiple alleles can produce modular variation in secondary sexual characteristics, including genital morphology, craniofacial morphology, gastrointestinal morphology, and home tank behaviors. These results provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of multiple alleles in populations.

The retina is challenged by the accumulation of vitamin A aldehyde adducts (bisretinoids) that photogenerate reactive oxygen species and photodecompose into damaging aldehyde- and dicarbonyl-bearing species. We sought to understand how Fe levels impact the retina, given that retinal pigment epithelial (RPE) cells are also challenged by accumulations of bisretinoids. We found that intracellular Fe promotes bisretinoid oxidation and degradation. This interpretation was supported by experiments showing that Fe chelation decreased the oxidative/degradation of the bisretinoid A2E in the presence of light and reduced cell death in cell-based experiments. Moreover, light-independent oxidation and degradation of A2E by Fenton chemistry products were evidenced by the consumption of A2E, release of dicarbonyls, and generation of oxidized A2E species in cell-free assays. These findings indicate that Fe is a key factor in the photodegradation of bisretinoids. Understanding the role of Fe in the photodegradation of bisretinoids may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of age-related macular degeneration. Predators are the drivers of ecosystems, and the evolution of their feeding strategies is fundamental to understanding how food webs work. However, the evolution of specialization is often considered a dead end, as predators become more specialized, they become less efficient and less able to adapt to environmental changes. Here we show that specialization can be maintained and even enhanced by morphological evolution. Our results suggest that the evolution of specialization is not a dead end, but rather a key process in the evolution of food webs.

The human hand is a complex and highly modified structure. The fossil record of the last 800,000 y is characterized by a suite of derived features that are absent in early hominins. This record is punctuated by the appearance of the third metacarpal styloid process, which is present in the Middle Pleistocene to recent human hand and absent in early hominins. The presence of this feature in a fossil from 1.42 Mya suggests that the complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato. This fossil also provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key derived characteristic of the modern human hand.

The one-carbon unit is essential for cell growth, and is provided by folate. Cancer cells have defects in folate metabolism, and thus depend on the enzyme serine hydroxymethyltransferase (SHMT) for one-carbon unit supply. Here we report the discovery of a pyrazolopyran scaffold that inhibits plant SHMT, and the development of dual SHMT inhibitors for cancer therapy. We also report a glycine import defect in diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, a cancer that is particularly sensitive to SHMT inhibition. These findings provide a metabolic rationale for SHMT inhibition in lymphoma, and a metabolic target for lymphoma therapy. They also suggest that SHMT inhibition is a promising strategy for B-cell malignancies. Finally, the pyrazolopyran scaffold is a promising lead for the development of novel SHMT inhibitors. Thus, this work provides a platform for the development of novel SHMT inhibitors for cancer therapy.

The role of natural landscapes in improving people’s diets is not well understood. This study shows that deforestation can reduce people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. Conversely, forest fragmentation can increase people’s consumption of fruits and vegetables and thus their vitamin A intake. These findings have important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also highlights the importance of using causal inference methods to understand the effects of environmental change on people’s diets. This is a relatively new field of research and there is a need to develop and apply these methods to better understand the impacts of environmental change on people’s diets.

Mechanization has greatly increased the capacity of agricultural machinery, allowing for higher output of food production. However, the increase in capacity has been accompanied by higher vehicle weights that increase risks of subsoil compaction. We show that while surface contact stresses remained nearly constant over the course of modern mechanization, subsoil stresses have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants.
